did.unittitle: J. Hartley Bowen collection of Aeronautical Materials Laboratory records

bioghist.p: During the 1940s and 1950s, J. Hartley Bowen (d. 1999) was the Technical Director of the Aeronautical Materials Laboratory (AML), which was formerly based at the Naval Air Engineering Center in Philadelphia. The AML conducted tests of the effects of radiation on nonmetalic substances, such as rubber and plastic. The lab also studied performance characteristics of preservatives used on mechanical components to prevent corrosion and rust.

scopecontent.p: This collection includes plans and specifications for facilities for nuclear radiation studies; minutes from meetings of the Nuclear Energy Programs Advisory Committee; materials relating to the physical relocation of the Aeronautical Materials Laboratory, including blueprints; specifications and reports on preservative agents and materials for aircraft, engines, and spare parts; a report on "Operation Crossroads," a series of tests on an aircraft that had been exposed to radiation; memos and news clippings about the Navy's plans to build a nuclear-powered seaplane; and a printed copy of the Hearing Before the US Congressional Subcommittee on Research and Development of the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy, held in July of 1959.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
